This is because a Fourier series can only represent periodic signals. If you want to represent a continuous aperiodic signal, then you need Fourier transform, which in some sense has a continuous spectrum (i.e. uncountable set of harmonics).

In terms of linear algebra, we know that, for finite-dimensional space, the number of basis vectors of a subspace $$S \subset V$$ cannot be greater than that of $$V$$. This may not be true for the infinite-dimensional case, but it gives you some intuition. The harmonics, i.e. $$\{e^{i\omega t}\}_{\omega=0}^{\infty}$$, can be thought as the basis of the space of all periodic signals, which is a subspace of all functions. (There are extra constraints about what kind of functions I can include; for example, delta function is a distribution, but somehow I can also find its Fourier series and transform in a generalized way). The space of all functions has a basis that is continuous in frequency and lead to the definition of Fourier transform

$$F(\omega) = \mathcal{F}\{f\} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t)e^{- i\omega t} dt $$

and its inverse
$$ f(t) = \mathcal{F}^{-1}\{F\} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} F(\omega)e^{ i\omega t} d\omega$$

I'd recommend taking Math185 and other functional analysis courses if you want to know some rigorous math.

Take EE120 if you haven't! It's the core of EE. All the EE subfields, including circuits, control/optimization, device physics (quantum physics), etc, will use the idea of Fourier analysis in one way or another.

For Discrete fourier series evaluated at N points per period, there are only N distinct harmonics: we can see from the euler form or from plotting harmonics that higher frequencies coincide with lower ones of the same modular value. If we extend N->inf, we get an infinite number of harmonics. But there seems to be a gap between this series and the proper Fourier series: the number of harmonics is by definition a countably infinite set, but the fourier series expresses continuous, periodic functions as a series of harmonics. Continuous implies real numbers, which are uncountable.

I don't think this has to do with definition of limit: Reimann integral bridges this gap because the sub-areas of integration can have irrational width, so as delta_x->inf, delta_x becomes irrational. But harmonics are integer multiplies of the fundamental harmonic, so there can only be a rational, countable number of them.

history.content:
For Discrete fourier series evaluated at N points per period, there are only N distinct harmonics, corresponding to N distinct cyclic groups on the points. If we extend N->inf, we get an infinite number of harmonics for infinite cyclic groups. But there is a gap between this series and the proper Fourier series: the number of harmonics is by definition a countably infinite set, but the fourier series expresses continuous, periodic functions as a series of harmonics. Continuous implies real numbers, which are uncountable.

I don't think this has to do with definition of limit: Reimann integral bridges this gap because the sub-areas of integration can have irrational width, so as delta_x->inf, delta_x becomes irrational. But harmonics are integer multiplies of the fundamental harmonic, so there can only be a rational, countable number of them.
